content: A Retrospective of House Rules Changes Since the 110th Congress examines how the majority party in the House organizes and writes the chamber's rules at the beginning of each new Congress. While the House largely adopts previous rules, changes are also made. This report is the second in a series, with the first one focusing on rules changes when Republicans took over the majority from Democrats. House Rules Changes from the 104th through the 109th Congress were examined, focusing on the extensive changes made when Republicans gained the majority in the House after 40 years of Democratic control. The report grouped the changes into five broad areas and further subdivided them by subject or Congress. The Democratic critique of Republican management during these Congresses was covered. The second report in the series continues with the Democratic majority in the 110th and 111th Congresses and the Republican majority in the 112th through 115th Congresses. It presents critiques of each party's management of the House during these periods. The report analyzes the critique by Democrats of Republican management of the House through the 109th Congress, the critique by Republicans of Democratic management of the House in the 110th and 111th Congresses, and Democratic policy differences with the changes made in rules resolutions from the 110th through the 115th Congresses. The changes are grouped into five broad subject areas and further subdivided by subject or Congress. The report analyzes critiques by Democrats and Republicans of each other's management of the House in various Congresses. It also examines the changes made in rules resolutions from the 110th through the 115th Congresses, organizing them into different subject areas. The report catalogs and explains changes to House rules affecting committees, the Chamber, budget legislation, House administration, and ethics standards in the 110th through the 115th Congresses. It supplements the House Rules and Manual.
